unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, my chacha, Dr. Sharma, keeps going on about rental yields when talking about his investment properties in Gurgaon. Frankly, I zone out half the time. But I *think* I'm starting to get it, and wanted to see what others think.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, my chacha, Doctor Sharma, keeps going on about rental yields when talking about his investment properties in Gurgaon. Frankly, I zone out half the time. But I think I'm starting to get it, and wanted to see what others think.

unnormalised: Basically, rental yield is how much money you make from rent compared to what you paid for the property. Higher yield = more money in your pocket, right? It's usually expressed as a percentage.
normalised: Basically, rental yield is how much money you make from rent compared to what you paid for the property. Higher yield equals more money in your pocket, right? It's usually expressed as a percentage.

unnormalised: Say you bought a flat in Mumbai for Rs. 1 Crore and rent it out for Rs. 25,000 per month. That's Rs. 3,00,000 a year. Your gross rental yield is (3,00,000 / 1,00,00,000) * 100 = 3%.
normalised: Say you bought a flat in Mumbai for rupee one crore and rent it out for rupee twenty five thousand per month. That's rupee three lakh a year. Your gross rental yield is (three lakh divided by one crore) multiplied by one hundred equals three percent.

unnormalised: But remember, that doesn't include property taxes, maintenance (like that leaky tap Raju fixed last week!), or periods when it's vacant. So, net yield is usually lower.
normalised: But remember, that doesn't include property taxes, maintenance (like that leaky tap Raju fixed last week!), or periods when it's vacant. So, net yield is usually lower.
